chapter.title: Virtualization Technology
chapter.para: Virtualization is a technology which provides a way for a machine (Host) to run another operating system (guest virtual machines) on top of the host operating system.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: Included with &sle; are the latest open source virtualization technologies, &xen; and &kvm;. With these s &sle; can be used to provision, de-provision, install, monitor and manage multiple virtual machines (VMs) on a single physical system. Out of the box, &sle; can create virtual machine running both modified, highly tuned, paravirtualized operating systems and fully virtualized unmodified operating systems. Full virtualization allows the guest OS to run unmodified and requires the presence of either Intel* Virtualization Technology (Intel VT) or AMD* Virtualization (AMD-V).

The primary component of the operating system that enables virtualization is an (or virtual machine monitor,)-- a layer of software that runs directly on server hardware. It controls platform resources, sharing them among multiple VMs and their operating systems by presenting virtualized hardware interfaces to each VM.

&sle; is an enterprise-class Linux server operating system that offers two types of s, &xen; and &kvm;. Both s support virtualization on 64-bit x86-based hardware architectures. Both &xen; and &kvm; support full virtualization mode. In addition, &xen; supports paravirtualized mode. &sle; with &xen; or &kvm; acts as a virtualization host server () that supports VMs with its own guest operating systems. The &suse; VM architecture consists of a and management components that constitute the , which runs many application-hosting VMs.
In &xen;, the management components run in a privileged VM often referred to as . In &kvm;, where the Linux kernel acts as the hypervisor, the management components run directly on the .

sect1.title: Virtualization Capabilities
sect1.para: Virtualization design provides a large number of capabilities in your organization:

listitem.para: Server Consolidation: Many server can be replaced by one big physical server, so hardware is consolidated, and Guest Operating System are converted to virtual machine.
Isolation: Guest operating system can be fully isolated from the Host running it. So if the virtual machine is corrupted, the Host system is not harmed.

Migration: A process to move a running virtual machine to another physical machines. Live migration is the extended features which allow this move without disconnection of the client or the application.
Disaster recovery: Guest are less dependent on the hardware, and the Host server provides snapshot features to be able to restore a know running system without any corruption.
Dynamic load balancing: migration feature brings a simple way to load balance your service across your infrastructure.

sect1.title: Virtualization Benefits
sect1.para: Virtualization brings a lot of advantages while providing the same service as Hardware server.
First it reduces the cost of your infrastructure. Server are mainly used to provide a service to customer, a virtualized operating system can provide the same service, with:

listitem.para: less Hardware: You can run several Operating System on one Host, so all hardware maintenance will be reduced.
Less power/cooling: less hardware means you don't need to invest more in electric power, backup power, and cooling if you need more service.
Save space: your data center space will be saved because you don't need more hardware server (less server than service running).
Less management: Using virtualized Guest simplify the administration of your infrastructure.

Agility and productivity: virtualization provides migration capabilities, and live migration, snapshots, this will reduce downtime, and will bring an easy way to move your service from one place to another one without any interruption.

sect1.title: Understanding Virtualization Modes
sect1.para: Guest operating systems are hosted on virtual machines in either full virtualization mode or paravirtual mode. Each virtualization mode has advantages and disadvantages.

listitem.para: Full virtualization mode lets virtual machines run unmodified operating systems, such as Windows* Server 2003, but requires the computer running as the &vmhost; to support hardware-assisted virtualization technology, such as AMD* Virtualization or Intel* Virtualization Technology.

Some guest operating systems hosted in full virtualization mode, can be configured to run the Novell* Virtual Machine Drivers instead of drivers originating from the operating system. Running virtual machine drivers improves performance dramatically on guest operating systems, such as Windows Server 2003. For more information, see .

Paravirtual mode does not require the host computer to support hardware-assisted virtualization technology, but does require the guest operating system to be modified for the virtualization environment. Typically, operating systems running in paravirtual mode enjoy better performance than those requiring full virtualization mode.
Operating systems currently modified to run in paravirtual mode are referred to as paravirtualized operating systems and include &productname; 11 and NetWareÂ® 6.5 SP8.

sect1.title: Hardware Assist Benefits
sect1.para: Intel* and AMD* provide virtualization hardware-assist technology. This reduce frequency of VM IN/OUT (less VM traps), because software is a major source of overhead, and increase the efficiency (the execution is done by the hardware). Moreover this reduce the memory footprint, provides a better resource control, and its allow secure assignement of specific I/O devices.
